questions.prompt: Provide the project codename or customer initiative name.
questions.placeholder: e.g., Opnix Refresh, Phoenix Revamp

questions.prompt: Select the project or product type that best describes this workstream.
questions.placeholder: Choose dominant delivery surface

questions.prompt: What problem does this initiative solve and for which users or customers?
questions.placeholder: Describe the primary user, their pain point, and the desired transformation.

questions.prompt: What measurable value or advantage should this solution deliver once successful?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Reduce onboarding time by 40%, increase retention, unlock a new market.

questions.prompt: How does this work align with current business strategy or OKRs?
questions.placeholder: Reference initiatives, KPIs, or mandates this project supports.

questions.prompt: Who is the executive sponsor and what decisions remain with them?
questions.placeholder: Name & role, plus escalation expectations.

questions.prompt: Who owns backlog prioritisation and scope trade-offs?
questions.placeholder: Name, role, availability, preferred contact channel.

questions.prompt: Who is accountable for technical direction and architecture sign-off?
questions.placeholder: Include backups for leave or timezone coverage.

questions.prompt: What is the agreed stakeholder communication cadence?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Weekly steering committee, daily stand-ups, async updates.

questions.prompt: List any areas requiring explicit RACI clarification (Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed).
questions.placeholder: Identify processes with unclear ownership so we can resolve them early.

questions.prompt: What primary success metrics must move and by how much?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Activation rate to 60%, NPS +10, MTTR < 30 minutes.

questions.prompt: What secondary metrics or guardrails must not regress?
questions.placeholder: Document supporting metrics (churn, latency, support volume, etc.).

questions.prompt: Describe qualitative indicators or anecdotes that would signal success or failure.
questions.placeholder: User feedback themes, stakeholder sentiment, demo reactions.

questions.prompt: List the key capabilities or deliverables explicitly in scope.
questions.placeholder: Use bullet list for features, workflows, or technical outcomes.

questions.prompt: List the capabilities or areas explicitly out of scope for this iteration.
questions.placeholder: Note any tempting additions that must wait.

questions.prompt: Define "done" for this engagement (technical, product, and documentation completeness).
questions.placeholder: Include acceptance gates like demos, sign-offs, or compliance checks.

questions.prompt: Document business or contractual constraints (launch dates, SLAs, regulatory deadlines).
questions.placeholder: List critical calendar commitments or contractual obligations.

questions.prompt: What technical standards or legacy requirements must we honour?
questions.placeholder: e.g., Must run on existing Kubernetes cluster, reuse auth provider, coding standards.

questions.prompt: Outline budgetary or tooling constraints that affect solution design.
questions.placeholder: Include licensing limits, cloud spend caps, approval processes.

questions.prompt: Summarise the current architecture or system topology we inherit.
questions.placeholder: Diagram references, key services, deployment model, observed pain points.

questions.prompt: Describe the target architecture vision or north-star state.
questions.placeholder: Note guiding principles, desired patterns, or technology shifts.

questions.prompt: List known technical debt hotspots that must be managed or paid down.
questions.placeholder: Include brittle modules, missing tests, scaling bottlenecks.

questions.prompt: Identify the core domain entities and relationships that matter most.
questions.placeholder: Use nouns that appear in user stories (e.g., Account, Workspace, Invoice).

questions.prompt: What upstream data sources or feeds do we consume?
questions.placeholder: Internal services, external vendors, manual imports, IoT devices.

questions.prompt: Describe expected data volume and velocity characteristics.
questions.placeholder: Peak throughput, batch windows, retention requirements.

questions.prompt: What data governance, lineage, or cataloguing practices must we follow?
questions.placeholder: Refer to privacy policies, GDPR, SOC2 controls, or data residency rules.

questions.prompt: Outline the testing pyramid (unit, integration, contract, e2e) and ownership.
questions.placeholder: Mention tools, coverage targets, and gating criteria.

questions.prompt: List required non-functional tests (performance, load, accessibility, chaos).
questions.placeholder: Include frequency and tooling expectations.

questions.prompt: What makes a feature story "ready" for implementation?
questions.placeholder: Acceptance tests, data requirements, UX assets, analytics tagging.

questions.prompt: Enumerate the top risks that could derail scope, schedule, or quality.
questions.placeholder: Include probability, impact, and mitigation ideas.

questions.prompt: List critical assumptions that must be validated early.
questions.placeholder: Dependencies on other teams, vendor commitments, dataset availability.

questions.prompt: Capture unanswered questions that need follow-up interviews or research.
questions.placeholder: Assign owners and due dates when possible.
